rComments: Absolutely loved Professor Stamp, she is really well versed in her field and is a fantastic lecturer. I attended every lecture because I actually enjoyed the curriculum and presentations. She began every lecture with a class-wide discussion which was super helpful and engaging

Truly an amazing professor. Super knowledgeable and her lectures were really interesting. Definitely go to her office hours, if you can't make her appointment time she will go out of her way to make a time that works for both of you. Very easy to talk to and inspired me to be a film major.
One of the best Film Professors on campus

Shelley is the best. Her lectures are really easy to follow and full of great information. She's very passionate about course material and easy to approach with questions. Definitely one of my favorite professors in UCSC's film department.
All around solid experience in Stamp's 20A class.  She is a seasoned pro and is a good lecturer.

Best class I've taken at UCSC so far. Focuses on making sure the students understand every aspect of lectures rather than trying to sound smart. Encourages class discussion and is really helpful in office hours. If you pay attention in class you should do fine. The textbook is a great supplement. Tests aren't easy but aren't ridiculous either.

You will get out of Shelley Stamp's class exactly what you put in. She has a lot of substance to offer, and if you do the reading, show up to lectures and watch films, you will learn a ton. She's really accessible outside of class, easy to talk to, and wrote a ground-breaking book on women in silent film. She's inspiring and always thoughtful.

She is the best teacher I have had at UCSC, her notes, slides and lectures are clear and to the point. If you go out of your way to jot down a couple of her own thoughts on films and use what she said in papers and tests you will easily ace the class. Also she is so helpful at office hours. Use them! Great class, interesting screenings and easy.

By far the best professor I have had at UCSC. She is clear and her lectures are well structured. You can also get away will missing class and screen films on your own time. She is amazingly helpful in her office hours. Its only two papers and two exams. Great class I totally recomend it and its really not very hard if you have half a brain.

Shelley is a good lecturer and she knows how to approach the subject of film in a way that beginners and non-majors can understand and enjoy. There were two essays, a midterm, and a final. The material wasn't hard to learn or understand, either.

We didn't have exams so much as timed essays (and a vocab section, but that's a piece of cake if you've been at all paying attention in discussions), so I can't speak for her crazy finals. But the essays were pretty basic, the films were interesting, and discussion was always interesting but not over my head. And, bonus, she's not that pretentious!

Stamp was amazing. Her lectures were the most interesting that i've ever experienced at UCSC. Yes, her final does cover all the readings and screenings, but if you've attended regularly then the final is no problem. She really knows the material and is a fun teacher. I loved her class.
Terrible teacher, we never had a clear picture of what we needed to learn and we were always lost when it came to papers and tests. She should be fired ASAP

Did not set up a good study enviorment when the final came up. I was lost on what to do with the papers, since we were writing about silent films that lasted about 7 minutes and had really simple storys. No study guide was the worst of it. No idea what was going to be expected of us on the test.

Shelley's class was by far the worst class I've ever taken at UCSC. 100% of the class was either screenings or discussions/lectures. Shelley made absolutely no attempt to make clear what information was important and what wasnâ€™t which made her final even more ridiculous. The final exam covered all lectures all discussions all readings and all scree

She is extremely knowledgable about the subject and her screenings were great, but, to quote her exactly, she "doesn't believe in study guides."  Thus you will find yourself struggling at the end desperately trying to figure out what will be on the final.  Study terms.  Study the reading.

Shelley rocks. I think she's a goth. At least I never saw her wear anything but black. And she knows her subject matter. On a personal note. I wouldn't have made it through school if not for her. She's one of the best at UCSC

After hearing from another prof. that I wrote about Double Indemnity in a previous class and for her (Stamps) film noir class, this warranted Stamp to accuse me of "clearly being academically dishonest" and plagiarizing myself (wtf?). After showing her how different the paper was she dropped the thing but really, how asinine can you get?

i didn't really like her class, or her teaching style, but when i missed the final, she let me re-take it (when i didn't think she would because she acted hard-ass all quarter).  so for that i will always be thankful.  it saved me from having to re-take the course.

i wanted to like shelley, but i just couldn't. she was always very snobby regarding film discussions. too much feminist emphasis (and i considered myself feminist!) a good portion of exam questions came from topics barely touched in class.
An excellent teacher!  Informative lectures, fairly easy assignments that are geared towards developing your research skills.  A fun class.
american film, weimar cinema: she's a good teacher, very nice, and approachable. she has good knowledge about material. looking forward to taking another class with her
